rules.description: Use Markdown H1 headings.
Aim for 50 to 60 characters; 80 characters maximum.
Start with an action verb in the imperative form and avoid the -ing form of the verb.
Capitalize only the first word and any proper nouns in sentence-style capitalization.
Focus the title on the outcome rather than the mechanics and prefer results over lists of actions.
examples: instead of "Install Node.js and create a project directory", use "Set up a local development environment for Node.js".

rules.description: Include the action and the object or context so the goal is unambiguous.
Avoid one- or two-word titles and empty verbs like make, manage, or put.
Do not use punctuation marks such as colons, semicolons, or dashes in titles.

examples.Example: Create a codespace from a template
Creating a codespace from a template
Use source control in your codespace
Collaborate with others in a codespace
Set up a live share session

sections.title: Subtitle

rules.description: Use a Markdown H4 for the subtitle placed directly under the H1 heading.
Write the subtitle as a single sentence without links, lists, or inline formatting.
End the subtitle sentence with a period.
Keep the subtitle under 20 words.
Use neutral verbs that state the purpose or benefit and avoid persuasive language.
Add new value beyond the title and do not repeat or rephrase the H1.

examples: **Title**: *Quickstart for GitHub Actions* / **Subtitle**: *Try out the core features of GitHub Actions in minutes*
**Title**: *Create a pull request* / **Subtitle**: *Create a pull request to propose and collaborate on changes to a repository*

sections.title: Access callout

rules.description: Omit the access callout entirely if no permission or product constraints exist.
Place the access callout after the title and subtitle and before the introduction.
Use the `Note` callout style for the access callout.
Use label-led, scannable content in the access callout and avoid explanations.
Include applicable permissions such as software roles or permission levels in the access callout.
Include applicable product versions or editions in the access callout.
Use commas to list multiple permissions or products in the access callout.
Do not include knowledge, skills, or required tools in the access callout.

examples: **Note** - **Permissions**: Node operators, Site operators - **Product**: Logos Storage v1.4.0 or later

sections.title: Callouts

rules.description: Use callouts sparingly and avoid placing them consecutively.
Use at most one callout per section.
Keep each callout concise with up to two short sentences and move longer content into the body under a heading.
Ensure callout content is directly relevant to the nearby task or decision point.
Use the appropriate callout type of `Tip`, `Note`, `Important`, or `Caution`.
Do not include full procedural steps or long prerequisite checklists inside callouts.
Refer to the writing rules for guidance on allowed callout types and when to use them.

examples: **Note:** Keep container resources within the documented limits to avoid throttling.

rules.description: Treat the intro section as guidance only and do not render a visible heading or body.
Include intro components in the order Overview, Decisions, Limits, Impact, then Prerequisites with optional items as marked.
Render the Overview, Decisions, Limits, Impact, and Prerequisites child blocks without their own headings.
Render the overview inline under the intro section without a visible subheading.
Write a 50–100 word paragraph explaining what the procedure covers, why it matters, and when to use it.
State where the procedure applies and who the intended audience is.
Optionally give one concrete real-world scenario in a single sentence.
Use at most one short alert only when it prevents confusion and otherwise keep the section free of callouts.
Render the decisions content inline under the intro section without a visible subheading.
Summarize decisions the reader must make before starting the procedure.
Use a list for simple choices and a compact table for multi-factor comparisons.
Focus decisions on actionable factors such as performance, complexity, cost, prerequisites, and limitations.
State trade-offs in the decisions explicitly.
Provide clear guidance on how to choose among options in the decision space.
examples: , "Choose A if you need X; choose B if you need Y".

rules.description: Link to a dedicated decision guide when the decision space is complex.
Render the limits content inline under the intro section without a visible subheading.
Describe constraints as a short paragraph and use a list or table only if it improves scanning.
Cover quotas, rate limits, timeouts, eventual consistency, and destructive side effects in the limits section.
Use a single concise callout for constraints that are critical to success or safety and refer to callout rules.
Mention a workaround or mitigation strategy when useful.
Link to a dedicated limitations page when details are lengthy.
Render the impact content inline under the intro section without a visible subheading.
Use a paragraph, list, or table format for the impact section.
Highlight side effects and risks in the impact section.
Note required privileges or safer alternatives when relevant to the impact.
Use a single concise callout for critical security impacts and link out for details.
Render the prerequisites content inline under the intro section without a visible subheading.
List only the technical setup needed to run the procedure such as software, versions, tools, and configuration.
Do not include roles, permissions, or product variants in prerequisites and place them in the access callout instead.
Prefer a single brief bullet list of noun phrases for prerequisites and link to install or setup instructions as needed.
Use a Markdown H2 with the exact text "What to expect" for this section.
Place the "What to expect" section after the introduction and before the first task section.
Include exactly one unordered list with three items and do not use code blocks or callouts in this section.
Write one complete sentence per bullet with at most two short sentences and end all sentences with a period.
Use parallel wording in each bullet with the same grammatical shape and focus on outcomes users will have after completing the procedure.
Order list items from most important to least important.
Allow only same-page heading links in this section and do not use external links.
Use Markdown H2 headings for procedure section titles.
Aim for 50–60 characters in task titles with a maximum of 80 characters.
Start each task title with an imperative verb and avoid the -ing form.
Write task titles in sentence case capitalizing only the first word and proper nouns.
Avoid empty verbs such as make, manage, or put in task titles.
Avoid one- or two-word task titles.
Do not use punctuation marks such as colons, semicolons, or dashes in task titles.
Write one or two short sentences in the task intro to provide context.
Do not repeat the task title wording in the task intro.
Add cross-references in the task intro rather than inside steps.
Use one callout after the task intro for important notes, warnings, or tips.
Do not place callouts between steps in a task.
Use at most one callout per task.
Use a numbered list when the task is completed in one go.
Use checkboxes when steps are unordered or spread over time.
Start each step with an imperative verb and avoid -ing forms.
Ensure each step represents one user action and combine only trivial actions.
Write ordered lists with `1.` for every item in the list.
Aim for 2–7 steps in a task and split the task if it is longer.
Avoid creating one-step tasks.
Insert a blank line and indent paragraphs, images, or code under a step so they are children of that step.
Bold UI elements such as buttons, menus, and options in steps.
Use inline code formatting for commands, filenames, paths, and output in steps.
Do not use external links in steps and allow only same-page anchors.
For UI paths, state the location before the action in the step text.
For conditions in steps, write the result first and then the condition.

examples.Incorrect (condition first): If the Network Status is "Disconnected", an error message will display.
examples.Correct (result first): An error message will display if the Network Status is "Disconnected".

examples.Incorrect (condition first): Only use the `$API_KEY` if you are calling the external service.
examples.Correct (result first): Use the `$API_KEY` only if you are calling the external service.

rules.description: Do not use numbered substeps or nested ordered lists beneath a step.
Use bullets for subactions such as clarifiers or alternatives under a step.
Limit clarifier bullet items to 2–4 in one level under a step.

Use an H2 Markdown heading for the FAQ or troubleshooting section.
Place this section after the final procedure section and before a "Next steps" section if present.
Begin the section heading with "Troubleshooting {topic}" for error resolution or "Frequently asked questions" for question-based content.
Use paragraphs, lists, or H3 headings for content in the FAQ or troubleshooting section.
Write H3 question headings in sentence case and end them with a question mark.
Use the term "Frequently asked questions" instead of "FAQ" alone.
Create a separate FAQ or troubleshooting concept article and link to it for longer or complex cases.
Treat the extra guidelines section as guidance only and do not render a visible heading or body.
Keep the overall procedure word count between 400 and 800 words.
Do not use H4, H5, or H6 headings in the document.
